greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: If S is countable finite set, we can define n as number of elements in S. There are n^n distinct functions f(S)->S. Each function has a fixed point, or an orbit in S. This sequence is a number of distinct functions g(S)->S, with largest orbit.
comment: Sizes of orbits are given by A000793.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..130
example: For S={a}, n=1 and only one operation possible {a->a}. For S={a,b}, n=2 and possible operations are {a->a,b->a}, {a->a,b->b}, {a->b,b->a},{a->b,b->b}. Longest orbit generated by applying operation {a->b,b->a}: initial set (a,b), applying function gives orbit - (b,a), (a,b). All other possible functions are generating fixed points.
results.author: Dmitriy Samsonov (dmitriy.samsonov(AT)gmail.com), Jul 10 2009
ext: a(0), a(10)-a(23) from _Alois P. Heinz_, Jul 12 2017
a(21)-a(22) corrected by _Alois P. Heinz_, Aug 16 2017
